title: 114_hr1713
content: The Act titled "Student Loan Repayment Assistance Act of 2015" excludes benefits from certain student loan payment assistance programs from gross income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act excludes student loan payment assistance from gross income for qualified employees who contribute at least $50 per month. The assistance is limited to $6,000 per year. The Act allows employers to provide student loan payment assistance to employees, with the exclusion from income not exceeding the employee's earned income for the year. A student loan payment assistance program must meet specific requirements outlined in the subsection. The student loan payment assistance program must not discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees and must benefit employees who qualify under a non-discriminatory classification set by the employer. Additionally, not more than 25 percent of the assistance can be provided to principal shareholders or owners. The program does not require funding and eligible employees must be notified of its availability. The employer must provide a statement of expenses to employees by January 31st, showing amounts paid for student loan assistance. The plan must not discriminate in favor of highly compensated employees and must benefit those who qualify under non-discriminatory classification. The paragraph discusses the requirement for average benefits provided to employees who are not highly compensated to be at least 55 percent of those provided to highly compensated employees under all plans of the employer. Salary reduction agreements may exclude employees with compensation less than $25,000. Compensation is defined by section 414(q)(4) unless determined otherwise by the employer. The text discusses requirements for employer plans to provide fair compensation without discrimination, direct contributions to lenders, and matching contributions for employee contributions. Definitions and special rules are outlined, including student loan payment assistance. The term 'student loan payment assistance' refers to paying principal or interest on indebtedness incurred by an employee for qualified higher education expenses. This includes education expenses paid within a reasonable timeframe before or after the debt was incurred, and for education received while the employee was an eligible student. Refinanced indebtedness is also covered. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets the requirements of the Higher Education Act of 1965 for any academic period. It excludes payments related to indebtedness owed to a related person or under certain qualified employer plans. The Education Act of 1965 defines terms like 'dependent,' 'earned income,' 'employee,' and 'employer.' Earned income excludes employer-paid student loan assistance. An employee includes self-employed individuals, and an employer is an individual with full ownership interest. The Education Act of 1965 defines terms related to employment, including 'employer' as an individual with full ownership interest in a business. A partnership is considered the employer of each partner who is an employee. Ownership rules for stock and unincorporated businesses are outlined in the Act. A student loan payment assistance program shall not fail to meet requirements merely because of utilization rates for different types of assistance. No deduction or credit allowed for excluded amounts from an employee's gross income. Matching contributions withheld from an employee under a student loan program are treated as salary reduction amounts. The contribution withheld from an employee under a student loan payment assistance program is treated as an amount paid by the employee, not the employer. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Code. Section 127A introduces student loan payment assistance programs. The effective date for the amendments is after the enactment of the Act. Section 3 discusses a deduction for student loan payments matched by an employer, with amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction for student loan payments made by qualified employees with matching contributions from employers is limited to $6,000 annually and $50,000 lifetime. Any amount excluded from an individual's gross income under section 127A will not be considered as an amount paid by the individual for tax purposes. The principal and interest for which a deduction is allowed under this section will not affect other deductions or credits allowed under the tax code.
